title: RAF Geilenkirchen
text:
Royal Air Force Geilenkirchen, more commonly known as RAF Geilenkirchen, was a <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force%20station">station</a> in the <a href="North%20Rhine-Westphalia">North Rhine-Westphalia</a> region of <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, built by the British who used the facility mainly as an airfield for RAF fighter squadrons from May 1953 until 21 January 1968.
History.
Post RAF history.
The RAF handed over the station to <a href="Germany">German</a> <a href="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> in March 1968. The Germans used the airfield as home for a Surface-to-Surface Missile Wing equipped with <a href="MGM-31%20Pershing">Pershing</a> missiles with support from the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>.
Current use.
In 1980, the station became <a href="NATO%20Air%20Base%20Geilenkirchen">NATO Air Base Geilenkirchen</a>, the main operating base for <a href="NATO">NATO</a>'s <a href="Airborne%20Early%20Warning%20and%20Control">Airborne Early Warning and Control</a> force, operating 14 <a href="Boeing%20E-3%20Sentry">Boeing E-3A Sentry</a> aircraft.
